speech.p: The House being met at half-past Two o'clock, and Mr. SPEAKER-ELECT having taken the Chair;

p.i: Message to attend the Lords Commissioners;

speech.p: The House went; and, having returned—

I have to report to the House that, in the House of Peers, Her Majesty, by Her Royal Commissioners, has been pleased to approve of the choice made of myself for the Office of Speaker, and that I have, in your name and on your behalf, made claim by humble Petition to Her Majesty to all your ancient and undoubted rights and privileges—particularly to the freedom of speech in debate, freedom from arrest, freedom of access to Her Majesty whenever occasion may require, and that the most favourable construction may be placed on all your proceedings. All these Her Majesty, by Her Commissioners, has been pleased to confirm in as ample a manner as they have ever been granted or confirmed by herself or by any of Her Royal Predecessors.
My first duty to the House is to repeat my very respectful acknowledgements and my grateful thanks for the great honour you have conferred upon me in placing me in the Chair.

I must now call upon the Members of the House, according to the usual custom, to take the Oath of Allegiance at the Table of the House, first doing so myself.
Thereupon Mr. SPEAKER first alone, standing upon the upper step of the Chair, took and subscribed the Oath.

It has proved convenient, to save confusion and to save hon. Members having to wait about in the Chamber, for the Chair to announce the order in which it proposes to call right hon. and hon. Members to take the Oath.
I propose to call first the Government Front Bench; then the Opposition Front Bench; then all Privy Councillors and former Ministers not included in those
two groups, wherever they may be seated. Thereafter, I go bench by bench—first the second bench below the Gangway on my right, and then the similar bench on my left, then the back bench below the Gangway on my right; then the similar bench on my left.
A diagram of how I propose to proceed has just been placed on the notice board in the Whips' offices and in the "No" Lobby. The seats are there given numbers, and the numbers will be on the annunciators so that hon. Members may not have to sit about for an unnecessarily long time. I know that I can count upon the honour of Members to observe the order which I have announced.

p.i: The following Members took and subscribed the Oath, or made and subscribed the Affirmation required by Law:

Order. I propose to suspend the Sitting and to return later. The Sitting is suspended until half-past Five o'clock.

Edward Macmillan Taylor, esquire, Glasgow, Cathcart.
Right honourable Reginald Ernest Prentice, East Ham, North.
Martin John McLaren, esquire, Bristol, North-West.
Edward Joseph Fletcher, esquire, Darlington.
Dudley Geoffrey Stewart-Smith, esquire, Belper.
Bernard John Hayhoe, esquire, Heston and Isleworth.
William Edward Garrett, esquire, Walls-end.
Richard Phipps Hornby, esquire, Ton-bridge.
Daniel Edmund Awdry, esquire, T.D., Chippenham.

Sir Harmar Nicholls, baronet, Peterborough.
Michael Cecil John Barnes, esquire, Brentford and Chiswick.
John Desmond Cronin, esquire, Loughborough.
Edward James Milne, esquire, Blyth.
Reginald Thomas Paget, esquire, Q.C., Northampton.
Ernie David Drummond Money, esquire, Ipswich.
George Grant, esquire, Morpeth.
Nigel John Spearing, esquire, Acton.
John Arbuthnot Ducane Wilkinson, esquire, Bradford, West.
Right honourable Richard Frederick Wood, Bridlington.
I propose to suspend the Sitting until quarter-past Six.

p.i: The following Members took and subscribed the Oath, or made and subscribed the Affirmation required by Law:

speech.p: Herbert John Harvey Parker, esquire, C.B.E., Dagenham.
William Thomas Williams, esquire, Q.C., Warrington.
William Griffiths, esquire, Manchester, Exchange.
Antony Claud Frederick Lambton, esquire, Berwick-upon-Tweed.
Eric Samuel Heffer, esquire, Liverpool, Walton.
Arthur Charles Latham, esquire, Paddington, North.
Harold Frederick Martin Woodnutt, esquire, Isle of Wight.
Arthur Montague Frank Palmer, esquire, Bristol, Central.
Arthur Davidson, esquire, Accrington.
Robert Alexander Lindsay, esquire, commonly called Lord Balniel, Hertford.
Ian Hedworth John Little Gilmour, esquire, Central Norfolk.
Sir John Galway Foster, K.C.B., Q.C., Northwich.
Robert Gordon Cooke, esquire, Bristol, West.
Winston Spencer Churchill, esquire, Stretford.
Norman Atkinson, esquire, Tottenham.
Ian MacArthur, esquire, Perth and East Perthshire.
Ian Mikardo, esquire, Poplar.
Thomas Gray Boardman, esquire, M.C., T.D., Leicester, South-West.
Order. The Sitting is suspended till a quarter to Seven.

p.i: The following Members took and subscribed the Oath, or made and subscribed the Affirmation required by Law:

speech.p: Thomas Galloway Dunlop Galbraith, esquire, commonly called the honourable Thomas Galloway Dunlop Galbraith, Glasgow, Hillhead.
Right honourable Hugh Charles Patrick Joseph Fraser, M.B.E., Stafford and Stone.
Gerard Folliott Vaughan, esquire, Reading.
James Anthony Stodart, esquire, Edinburgh, West.
Right honourable Frederick William Mulley, Sheffield, Park.
Jeffrey Howard Archer, esquire, Louth.
William Rupert Rees-Davies, esquire, Isle of Thanet.
Robert Chichester-Clarke, esquire, Londonderry.
Eric Ogden, esquire, Liverpool, West Derby.
Frank Julian Allaun, esquire, Salford, East.
Resolved, That this House do now adjourn till Tomorrow at Eleven o'clock.—[Mr. Pym.]
